etymologies: mid 17th century (in the sense ‘unforeseen occurrence’): from medieval Latin emergentia, from Latin emergere ‘bring to light’ (see emerge)

definitions: the process of coming into view or becoming exposed after being concealed

examples.text: I misjudged the timing of my emergence

shortDefinitions: process of becoming visible after being concealed

definitions: the escape of an insect or other invertebrate from an egg, cocoon, or pupal case

examples.text: the parasite's eggs hatch synchronously with the emergence of the wasp larvae

shortDefinitions: escape of insect or other invertebrate from egg

definitions: an outgrowth from a stem or leaf composed of epidermal and subepidermal tissue, as the prickles on a thistle plant.
shortDefinitions: outgrowth from stem or leaf composed of epidermal and subepidermal tissue

definitions: the process of coming into being, or of becoming important or prominent

examples.text: the emergence of the environmental movement
Japan's emergence as a modern state

shortDefinitions: process of coming into existence or prominence
